addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Robert Cecill knight one of her Hig
es
privy Councel.

8 Ma
r
1594
M
r
Bodley to my M
r
. From
e Haghe./

page.lettertext:
fol.94r
May it please yo
r
H. to be advertised,
at accor-
ding to yo
r
l
re
of
e 21 of Fe
b
w
ch
I have recea-
ved, and humbly thanke yow for it, I am greatly
desirous, to take any fitte course,
at
S
r
Horace
might
be paied. The debt hath bin required by my
proposition, not as
e rest in general termes, but as
desired by her
Ma
tie
to be first of all discharged,
and I looke for an answear every day. There-
after as they frame it, I must referre it to her Ma
tie
or replie up
o
it heere: wherein I will not omitte
to alleage for S
r
Horace, w
at
is meetest for his
purpose: and to drawe them, if I can, to acknow-
ledge those 2 pointes, w
ch
yo
r
H. hath sette downe.
Howbeit I have signified already by a former unto
yow, wherup
o
they will insist, as I ghessed by
e
speeches, w
ch
I had w
t
some in privat. If once
ei
should dischardge a debt of
at nature, they are so
muche afraid of
e consequence of it, as I make
full account, I shall sooner winne them to rembourse
to her Hig
es
a great summe of mony by vertu of that
right, whereby she doth demaunde this g
nr
al restitu-
tion, then any litle debt
at was made by them in
Brabant.
Nevertheles I will doe my best endevo
r
,
sith it is her Hig
es
pleasure, it being sufficient to make
me imploy all my wittes, though yo
r
H. commenda-
tion might move me to doe any thing, and otherwise
of my self I will be weery of no paines in any cause
of S
r
Horace Pallavicine. For mater of
occurrence, this is all that we have, that
e castle
of
Huy
in
e la nd of Luycke, w
ch
we surprised of
late, is besieged by
La Motte
. His forces are be-
tween fower and 5000 foote, and towardes 500 horse.
fol.94v
The Governo
r
of
e Castle
Harangieres,
who is a very
sufficient and resolute soldier, hath written to
Count
Maurice
,
at he hopes to hold his owne. He hath men
enough w
t
in, and provision sufficient, both of victual,
powder and munition. It is also supposed that after
a couple of monethes, there will be meanes for the
states to rescue
e place. It is written for
certaine from
Andwerp,
at
e
Count de Fuentes
, doth
governe all by provision in
e Enemies affaires: but
they say
e greater part of
e nobilitie of those Pro-
vinces, are gone from
Brussels
to their homes.
And
thus I take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage.
Ma
r
8 1594.
Yo
r
H. at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley
